thread.title: CU volleyball: Buffs fall flat against No. 12 UCLA
thread.title_full: CU volleyball: Buffs fall flat against No. 12 UCLA

author:
Pat Rooney 

BuffZone.com Writer
title: CU volleyball: Buffs fall flat against No. 12 UCLA
text:
CU volleyball: Buffs fall flat against No. 12 UCLA CU can't find spark while swept at home 
BuffZone.com Writer Posted: 10/11/2015 03:31:44 PM MDT 
On Friday, as the University of Colorado volleyball team welcomed the nation's No. 1 team to town, the Buffaloes hit the Coors Events Center floor with a fury and passion that gave the USC Trojans all they could handle. 
Suffice to say, Sunday was a different story. 
The Buffs lacked that same energy against No. 12 UCLA, and the Bruins pounced early and never let up, sending CU to a 3-0 defeat in a Pac-12 Conference showdown. 
"After this epic, high-level, great match Friday night, there is a physical component and fatigue is there, but that is something that as high-level players and teams that we have to deal with," CU coach Liz Kritza said. "(UCLA) played a match that I don't think was as taxing Friday night. 
"For us, the biggest thing is we know we can play at the highest level with any team. And when we don't, I think there's some frustration that sets in and it kind of gets us off what our normal pace is. I think that's really what it was." 
CU (10-8, 2-4) held a slim lead through much of the first set but received an unfortunate break late on an official's decision. The Buffs had seemingly taken a 19-15 lead when a UCLA spike failed to clear the net. However, the official on the opposite side of the play ruled that CU senior Nicole Edelman had grazed the ball at the net, turning that 19-15 edge back into a far more precarious 18-16 lead. Advertisement 
From there, the Buffs failed to push the Bruins to a set-point opportunity, with UCLA eventually claiming a 26-24 decision. CU never regained the momentum, falling behind 9-1 in the second set as the Bruins cruised to a 22-15 win and leading only at 2-1 in the third set before UCLA steadily pulled away. 
"The spark that we had on Friday night wasn't really there," CU junior Cierra Simpson said. "There were traces of it in the first set, but it felt like we fell flat after the first set. Just maybe we got a little discouraged a little bit after losing. We've got to learn from that and correct it for next weekend." 
Alexis Austin finished with a team-leading 12 kills for the Buffs while Simpson added 16 digs. UCLA's Jordan Anderson proved tough to stop throughout the match for CU, finishing with a game-high 20 kills. The Bruins' Claire Felix, a Colorado Springs native and a former club teammate of Simpson, recorded six kills and three blocks. 
One week after posting a much-needed comeback win on the road against then-No. 22 Oregon, the Buffs will be desperate for positive results during another demanding home set next weekend against Cal on Friday and No. 7 Stanford on Sunday. 
"It's a tough loss, but quite honestly I have more confidence in my players than ever," Kritza said. "They have it in themselves. We will be absolutely fine. We have to re-tool a few things, we've got to let some people recover and stave off some injuries ... and then we make sure that we regroup and we have two more tough teams coming in here. Our focus has to be making sure we take care of business and protect our home floor better than we did this weekend." 
Pat Rooney: rooneyp@dailycamera.com or twitter.com/prooney07 
UCLA 3, CU 0 UCLA (13-3, 4-2) 26 25 25 CU (10-8, 2-4) 24 15 19 
Kills — UCLA : Anderson 20, Buechler 11, Lawless 8; CU : Austin 12, G. Simpson 8. 
Blocks — UCLA : Frager 4, Felix 3, Buechler 3; CU : Abu 4. 
Assists — UCLA : Chandler 46; CU : Edelman 34. 
Aces — UCLA : Chandler 2, Drolson 2; CU : C. Simpson 1. 
Digs — UCLA : Formico 12, Chandler 7, Drolson 6; CU : C. Simpson 16, Edelman 8.
